awd_titl_txt: Gravitational Wave Transient Astrophysics with LIGO
awd_abstract_narration:
The direct detection of gravitational waves, tiny oscillations of the curvature of space-time that were predicted 100 years ago by Einstein's theory of General Relativity, was a groundbreaking event for gravitational physics.  On September 14, 2015, The Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) made the first direct detection of gravitational waves, which in this case were produced by the collision of two black holes nearly 1.4 billion light years away from Earth. Since then, several more black hole collisions have been detected by LIGO and its European counterpart, Virgo. Then, on August 17, 2017 LIGO and Virgo detected a new type of signal, from the coalescence of two neutron stars, in coincidence with a gamma ray burst. Over 70 observatories have participated in following up this detection in almost every possible electromagnetic wavelength, and a richness of information is now available on this unique event. The era of gravitational-wave enabled, multi-messenger astronomy has officially begun. This award supports critical LIGO research at the Georgia Institute of Technology, for the detection, characterization and astrophysical interpretation of gravitational wave transient signals in LIGO data, at a new frontier in science that aims a deeper understanding of the universe.  The award will benefit from the long term collaboration of the PI and co-PI and a synergistic team at the Georgia Tech Center for Relativistic Astrophysics, with experts in computational astrophysics, cosmology, particle astrophysics, astronomy, the college of computing and a strong outreach program in Atlanta, enhanced by the new ties to the LIGO Scientific Collaboration, and a firm commitment to diversity and the role of women in STEM.

The award supports an active LIGO group at Georgia Tech, with work on two topics of critical importance to the LIGO mission: 1) Participation in the LSC-Virgo Burst all-sky, morphology-independent search for gravitational transients, sensitive to a wide range of signatures, including core-collapse supernovae, coalescence of neutron star and/or black hole binary systems and neutron star oscillations, including characterization of LIGO data to enable scientific discovery, to deliver the data quality information necessary to clean the data sets and veto false positives, and to identify data quality issues early enough that they can be mitigated in the instruments. 2) Integration of generic analytical and numerical relativity waveforms in searches and interpretations of signals from a variety of astrophysical sources, especially in those sources where the strong field of gravity is at its peak and information provided by numerical relativity is at its most influential, such as intermediate mass black hole mergers, follow-up simulations of exotic sources, and consistency tests of waveform models. With this award, the Georgia Tech group will contribute to core science of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC), capitalizing on existing resources and expertise, and enabling advanced LIGO science of highest priority while stimulating intellectual curiosity and exploring novel approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the award's duration, the LIGO-Virgo Collaboration embarked on an ambitious journey to explore the universe through gravitational waves. This award supported the contributions made by Georgia Tech's LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC) members in pursuit of core LIGO science goals, enabling LIGO Science, and advancing gravitational-wave astrophysics in the multi-messenger era.

Goal 1. Enabling LIGO science: 

Leadership and Collaboration Management: Early in the award, the Principal Investigator (PI) served as LSC deputy spokesperson, focusing on results from the second science run (O2) and preparing the public release of O2 data, as well as preparations for the third science run (O3) and the release of public alerts. Furthermore, the PI co-edited the new LSC Bylaws and the re-organization of the LSC to adapt to the post-detection era. She then led the new LSC Division of Collaboration Standards and Services, shaping collaboration policies and fostering a strong collaborative environment.

Software Infrastructure and Data Analysis: Georgia Tech's LIGO team made significant contributions to software infrastructure for LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA collaboration analyses that resulted in the Gravitational Wave Transient Catalogs (GWTC-1, GWTC-2, GWTC-3). Their work on BayesWave, a software package modeling gravitational wave signals using wavelet functions and modeling instrument noise as a combination of a parametrized Gaussian and non-Gaussian noise transients, was crucial for completing O3 data analyses and preparing for the O4 run. Improvements to code-release infrastructure, workflow automation, and operation on the Open Science Grid enhanced the pipeline's efficiency. Moreover, the team's involvement in waveform reconstruction comparisons using BayesWave allowed for more accurate interpretations of gravitational wave signals. The team also studied the impact of noise transients (glitches) on black hole binary waveform reconstructions with BayesWave, and tested on O3 noise transients the potential to use BayesWave  to separate coherent and incoherent parts of the signal for glitch modeling and subtraction in future GW detections. Finally, the team significantly contributed to RIFT, a next-generation parameter estimation pipeline for binary black hole coalescences. Most notably, they enbled its usage on the Open Science Grid and developed an automatization engine.

Goal 2: Gravitational-wave Astrophysics in the Multi-messenger Era

Astrophysics from Binary Neutron Star Mergers (BNS): The team contributed infrastructure for searching post-merger signals following binary neutron star coalescences. Their analysis of BNS candidate event GW190425, using BayesWave to search for coherent power in the detector network following the BNS merger, placed upper limits on signal amplitude and energy radiated, consistent with GW170817.

Gravitational Waves from Binary Black Hole Mergers (BBH): With combined support from this award and PHY-1806580, the team tested the impact of physics beyond waveform approximants used in LIGO-Virgo template searches,  to find ways to incorporate information at merger into the interpretation of BBH sources. Their innovative method for measuring the final spin of remnant black holes, independent of templates, was implemented into a BayesWave search and tested against O3 observations. The team also tuned the RIFT algorithm to use numerical relativity waveforms and expanded the Numerical Relativity Catalog in use by the LIGO-Virgo Collaboration.

Intermediate Mass Black Hole Binaries (IMBH): The team led the effort for an IMBH methods paper, analyzing errors in constraining IMBH parameters using numerical relativity waveforms. They played a lead role in the search for IMBHs in the first two observing runs and developed a formalism to directly utilize numerical relativity waveforms for astrophysical constraints. Analysis of GW190521, a candidate IMBHB coalescence, with RIFT and BayesWave furthered their investigation into these enigmatic objects. Finally, they analyzed GW170502 using two state-of-the-art surrogate models, enhanced by higher modes, to tighten constraints on this candidate.

Residual Analysis and Tests of General Relativity: Georgia Tech led the development of the BayesWave residual analysis for a model-independent test of General Relativity. The inclusion of higher modes in the waveform models improved the estimate of mass ratio and confirmed the agreement between waveform-based and more flexible wavelet-based analyses.

Multimessenger analysis: The team developed a hierarchical approach to analyze sub-threshold multimessenger events, facilitating offline searches for gravitational-wave/neutrino coincidences and gravitational waves in coincidence with long or sub-threshold Gamma Ray Bursts (GRB) or Fast Radio Bursts (FRB). Active engagement with the LIGO-Virgo GRB group resulted in significant contributions to several GRB- and FRB- triggered searches (e.g. GRB190427A, GRB190804058, GRB190822705, FRB54296780, FRB36154193, FRB40608623). 

In summary, this award enabled significant strides in support of LIGO Science, advancing gravitational-wave astrophysics, and contributing to the understanding of the universe through gravitational waves, laying a strong foundation for future discoveries in this exciting field.
